title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
text:
NoteSurvey Terminology




A population is a group of objects or people we wish to study.
A parameter is a numerical value that characterizes some aspect of the population.
A census is a survey which measures every member of the population.
A sample is a sub-collection of objects or people taken from the population of interest.
A statistic is a numerical characteristic of the sampled data; it is sometimes called an estimator, and the numerical results are called the estimates.









TipExample 7.1.1.




QuestionAnswer


Data is gathered on the heights of all NBA basketball players. The mean of the data is calculated.

The _________ is all NBA players.
The _________ is the mean height of all NBA players.




The population is all NBA players.
The parameter is the mean height of all NBA players.












TipExample 7.1.2.




QuestionAnswer


A researcher is interested in studying the heights of American women. She takes a random sample of 1,500 American women and finds the mean height of the sample is 63.6 inches.

The _________ is the 1,500 American surveyed.
The _________ is the sample mean of 63.6 inches. The researcher may _________ that the average American woman is 63.6 inches tall.




The sample is the 1,500 American surveyed.
The statistic is the sample mean of 63.6 inches. The researcher may estimate that the average American woman is 63.6 inches tall.












NoteStatistical Inference




Statistical inference is the science of drawing conclusions about a population based on observing characteristics of samples.
Statistical inference involves uncertainty because the entire population is not being measured.
An important component of statistical inference is measuring the uncertainty.









NoteStatistics vs. Parameters




Statistics are measurable—any time we collect data, we find the value of a statistic.
Parameters are typically unobservable—they can be estimated with statistics, but these estimates will involve some degree of certainty.









NoteNotation



In general, Greek letters are used to represent population parameters, whereas Latin letters are used to represent statistics.









Statistics (based on sample data)
Symbol
Parameters (typically unknown)
Symbol




Sample Mean
\(\overline{x}\)
Population Mean
\(\mu\)


Sample Standard Deviation
\(s\)
Population Standard Deviation
\(\sigma\)


Sample Variance
\(s^2\)
Population Variance
\(\sigma^2\)


Sample Proportion
\(\hat{p}\)
Population Proportion
\(p\)











TipExample 7.1.3.




QuestionAnswer


The mean GPA of all 5,000 students at Uneeda College is 2.78. A sample of 50 GPAs from this college has a mean of 2.93.

What is the population?
What is the sample?
What value is the parameter? What symbol do we use to represent this value?
What value is the statistic? What symbol do we use to represent this value?



a. The population is all 5,000 students at Uneeda College. b. The sample consists of the 50 students whose GPAs were recorded. c. The parameter is the mean GPA of 2.78; we write \(\mu = 2.78\). d. The statistic is the mean GPA of 2.93; we write \(\bar{x} = 2.93\).











NoteBias



A survey method is biased if it has a tendency to produce an inaccurate or untrue value. There are three common types of bias:

Measurement bias
Sampling bias
Estimator bias—the use of an estimator that is biased









NoteMeasurement Bias




Results from asking questions that do not produce a true answer; occurs when measurements tend to record values larger or smaller than the true value.
Sources of measurement bias:


Self reporting data
Confusing or leading survey questions
Non-neutral survey questions









NoteSampling Bias



Sampling bias occurs when a sample is used that is not representative of the population.








NoteQuestions to Ask About Sampling




What percentage of people who were asked to participate actually did so?
Did the researchers select the participants, or did the individuals choose to participate themselves?









NoteSimple Random Sampling




Draw subjects at random from the population without replacement.
A random sample is one in which every member of the population is equally likely to be chosen for the sample.
A true random sample is difficult to achieve.
Statisticians have developed methods for producing random samples that can be used to estimate characteristics of populations.

title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
text:
Section 7.1 Examples






TipExample 1.




QuestionAnswer


In January 2015, the Pew Research Center published a report stating that 37% of Americans believed that genetically modified foods were safe to eat. This was based on a survey of 2002 American adults.

What is the population?
What is the sample?
What was the parameter of interest?
What is the statistic?



a. The population is all American adults. b. The sample consists of the 2002 American adults surveyed. c. The parameter is proportion of all American adults who believed that GMOs were safe to consume. d. The statistic is 0.37.











TipExample 2.




QuestionAnswer


A high school wants to measure how often students vape, so the administration asks teachers to survey students via a hand-raise asking them if they vape. Why might this produce a measurement bias?


Students may not want to admit to vaping in front of their teachers and peers. This would lead to inaccurate count of the students who vape.











TipExample 3.




QuestionAnswer


Internet polls are very common with local news organizations. Why might internet polls produce a sampling bias?


Internet polls may produce a sampling bias because they only include individuals who have internet access and are willing to participate in online surveys. This may exclude certain demographics, leading to a non-representative sample.











TipExample 4.




QuestionAnswer


Identify possible biases from each of the following situations

A survey of college students’ music preferences asks “Do you like rock music or another genre?”
Suppose the county commissioners want to know if the county residents support constructing a new high-rise on the beach. They send out a survey to only beach residents.



a. The question is leading because it suggests that rock music is the preferred choice. b. The sample is biased because it only includes beach residents, who may have different opinions than non-beach residents.











TipExample 5.




QuestionAnswer


Suppose you want to estimate the mean GPA of all students at your school. You set up a table in the library asking for volunteers to tell you their GPAs. Do you think you would get a representative sample? Why or why not?


No. Students who volunteer to report their GPA may be more likely to have higher GPAs, leading to a sampling bias.











TipExample 6.




QuestionAnswer


An August 2022 article from Forbes magazine read:
“Results are in from the Florida’s first mandated system-wide survey of”intellectual freedom and viewpoint diversity” at its public universities, and one indisputable conclusion can be drawn from it: most students, staff, and faculty ignored it, yielding little in the way of trustworthy results. The survey was required when Florida’s Republican-controlled Legislature at the urging of Governor Ron DeSantis, enacted House Bill 233, creating section 1001.73(13), in Florida Statutes, entitled INTELLECTUAL FREEDOM AND VIEWPOINT DIVERSITY ASSESSMENT…Of the 368,000 college students who received the voluntary survey, 8,835, a measly 2.4%, completed it, according to the report presented Friday to the Florida Board of Governors, which oversees the State University System of Florida.”
The survey included questions such as: “How should colleges or universities handle students who disrupt invited speakers and prevent them from speaking?”” followed by a list of punitive measures. What biases, if any, do you find from this survey?


The low response rate (2.4%) indicates a likely sampling bias, as those who chose to respond may have different views than the overall population of students, staff, and faculty. Additionally, the wording of the question about disruptive students may introduce measurement bias, as it frames the issue in a way that could influence respondents’ answers.











TipExample 7.




QuestionAnswer


A phone survey asked whether Social Security should be continued or abandoned immediately. Only landlines (not cell phones) were called. Do you think this would introduce bias? Explain.


Yes. This would likely introduce sampling bias because individuals who only use cell phones (often younger demographics) are excluded from the survey, potentially skewing the results towards the opinions of older individuals who are more likely to have landlines.











TipExample 8.




QuestionAnswer


A school district is interested in finding out what percentage of voters in the district would favor the passage of a school bond measure. The district sends out a survey to all school parents asking, “Do you favor the passing of a school bond measure to provide additional resources to improve educational opportunities for your students?” Identify any sources of possible bias in this survey.


The question is leading, as it suggests that passing the bond measure will improve educational opportunities, which may influence respondents to answer favorably. Additionally, only parents of students in the school district are surveyed, which may not represent the views of all voters in the district.

title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
section: Section 7.2: Measure the Quality of a Survey
text:
Section 7.2: Measure the Quality of a Survey

Statistical Inference
One of the most import application of statistics is statistical inference, which is the process of using data from a sample to make estimates or test hypotheses about the characteristics of a population. However, since we are using a sample to make inferences about a population, there is always some uncertainty involved. Fortunately, we can quantify this uncertainty by measuring the quality of our estimates. Two important aspects of the quality of an estimate are its accuracy and precision.






NoteAccuracy vs. Precision




Accurate: The measurement process captures the intended quantity; it correctly estimates the population parameter.
Precise: If the measurement process is repeated, the estimates are very consistent.














TipExercise 1. Sample Proportion Distribution.




Instructions



Log into the computer station in front of you.
Scan the first QR code in the margin to take a quick survey.
Open a browser on your computer station and go to https://ckaoxvii.github.io/sample_proportion_distribution/.












Survey









NoteSampling Distribution



Recall: Samples may be used to make inferences about a population. Taking repeated samples form a population create a distribution of sample statistics, called the sampling distribution.

The estimator \(\hat{p}\) (sample proportion) is an unbiased estimator, as long as the samples are random.
The precision improves as sample size increases.
The shape of the sampling distribution is more symmetric as sample size increases.









NoteCalculating Bias and Standard Error



Suppose that

the samples are randomly chosen from the population, and
if the sampling is without replacement, the population is at least 10 times larger than the sample size.

Then

the bias of \(\hat{p}\) is 0, and
the standard error (SE) of \(\hat{p}\) is given by \[
SE = \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}},
\] where \(p\) is the population proportion and \(n\) is the sample size.

QuestionAnswer


According to the website VGCharts1, as of June 2021, PS5 had a total global sales of 9,748,029 units, where as Xbox Series X/S had a total global sales of 5,815,532 units. Use the webapp from Exercise 1 to complete parts b through e.

Find the population proportion, \(p\), of PS5, out of the combined total global sales of both consoles.
Use the population proportion from part a and a sample size of 10, find the mean of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion \(\hat{p}\) after 10 simulations. Is the \(\hat{p}\) from each simulation necessarily the same as \(p\)?
Repeat part b and find the mean of the sampling distribution of the sample proportion of \(\hat{p}\) after 100 simulated samples.
Repeat this simulation using 100 simulated samples, but with a sample size of \(n = 50\). What did you notice about the shape of the distribution of \(\hat{p}\)?
Do this one more time but with a sample size of \(n = 100\). How is the shape of the distribution of \(\hat{p}\) different this time? What is your standard deviation? Calculate the SE by hand and compare.



a. The population of both consoles is \[
  9748029 + 5815532 = 15563561.

  p = \frac{9748029}{15563561} \approx 0.626.
\] b. The mean of the sampling distribution of \(\hat{p}\) is approximately 0.55 after 10 simulations. The \(\hat{p}\) from each simulation is not necessarily the same as \(p\). c. The mean of the sampling distribution of \(\hat{p}\) is approximately 0.632 after 100 simulations. d..

title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
section: Section 7.3. Central Limit Theorem for Sample Proportions
text:
Section 7.3. Central Limit Theorem for Sample Proportions






NoteApplication of the Central Limit Theorem to Sample Proportions




The central limit theorem can be used to estimate proportions in a population.
The central limit theorem can tell us that, if some basic conditions are met, the sampling distribution of the sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\)) will be approximately normal.









NoteThe Central Limit Theorem (CLT) for Sample Proportions



If we take a random sample from a population, and if the sample size is sufficiently large and the population size much larger than the sample size, then the sampling distribution of \(\hat{p}\) is approximately normal with a mean of \(p\) and a standard deviation of \[
  \text{SE} = \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}},
\] where \(n\) is the sample size.

If the value of \(p\) is unknown, we can use \(\hat{p}\) in place of \(p\) to estimate the standard error.









NoteConditions for the Applicability of the CLT for Sample Proportions




Sampling is random and independent.
Large sample size: The sample size \(n\), is large enough that the sample expects at least 10 successes and 10 failures. That is, \[
\begin{align*}
\text{Number of Successes}: &= np \geqslant 10,\\
\text{Number of Failures}: &= n(1-p) \geqslant 10.
\end{align*}
\]
Large population: If the sampling is done without replacement, the population must be at least 10 times the sample size.









NoteThe Central Limit Theorem and the Empirical Rule



If the conditions for the central limit theorem are met, the probability that a sample proportion will fall within two standard errors of the population proportion is approximately 95%.

title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
section: Section 7.4. Estimating the Population Proportion with Confidence Intervals
text:
Section 7.4. Estimating the Population Proportion with Confidence Intervals

Use the central limit theorem to construct a confidence interval.







Note



We now focus on inferential statistics. Often it is easy to calculate statistics from a sample, but it is difficult (and sometimes impossible) to calculate parameters from a population.



Creating a Confidence Interval for Estimating the Population Proportion






TipExample 7.4.1.




QuestionAnswer


According to pewresearch.org, an October 2016 article indicated that 685 of 1,201 adults randomly surveyed favor the legalization of marijuana.

What percent of the adults surveyed supported the requirement to legalize marijuana?
Is the value in part (a) a sample statistic or a population parameter?
Do you know the percentage of all American adults (\(p\)) that support legalization of marijuana?
Do you think the percent of adults surveyed who support the requirement is exactly equal to the percent of all American adults who support legalization? That is, is our sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\)) exactly equal to the population proportion (\(p\))?



a. The percent of adults surveyed who supported legalization is \[
\hat{p} = \frac{685}{1201} \approx 0.5704 \text{ or } 57.04\%.
\] b. The value in part (a) is a sample statistic. c. No, we do not know the percentage of all American adults (\(p\)) that support legalization of marijuana. d. No, we do not think that the sample proportion (\(\hat{p}\)) is exactly equal to the population proportion (\(p\)).





From the previous sections, we know the following facts:

Our estimator, \(\hat{p}\), is an unbiased estimator of the population proportion, \(p\). Therefore, the population parameter, \(p\), should be close to our sample statistic, \(\hat{p}\).
The standard error is estimated as \[
\text{SE}_{\text{est}} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.57(1-0.57)}{1201}} \approx 0.0143.
\]
Since the sample size is large, the probability distribution of \(\hat{p}\) is approximately normal and centered around the true population proportion.
There is about a 95% chance that \(\hat{p}\) is within two standard errors of population proportion \(p\). Thus, \[
2 \times \text{SE} = 2 \times 0.0143 = 0.0286.
\]
Therefore, we are 95% confident that the value of the true population proportion is within 2.86 percentage points of 0.57.
Hence, we are 95% confident that the true population proportion (i.e., the proportion of all American adults who support legalization of marijuana) is between \[
0.57 - 0.0286 = 0.5414
\] and \[
0.57 + 0.0286 = 0.5986.
\] This is called a confidence interval.







NoteConfidence Interval



Confidence intervals provide us with

A range of possible values for a population parameter.
A confidence level, which express our level of confidence that the interval contains the true population parameter.
Tells us that how often the estimation is successful.
Measure the success rate of the method, not of any one particular interval.









NoteMargin of Error



The margin of error tells us how far from the population parameter our estimate can be. \[
  \text{Margin of Error} = z^* \times \text{SE}_{\text{est}},
\] where \(z^*\) indicates the number of standard errors to include in the margin of error.
From the empirical rule, we know that

\(z^\ast = 1\) corresponds with an approximate confidence level of 68%;
\(z^\ast = 2\) corresponds with an approximate confidence level of 95%;
\(z^\ast = 3\) corresponds with an approximate confidence level of 99.7%.









NoteConfidence Level & Margin of Error



The table below shows the more precise \(z^\ast\) values for some frequently used confidence levels.

NoteConfidence Interval for a Population Proportion.



Confidence intervals are of the form: \[
\hat{p} \pm m,
\] where \(m\) is the margin of error. Since \(m = z^\ast \cdot \text{SE}\), where \(\text{SE}\) is the standard error, the confidence interval is \[
  \hat{p} \pm z^\ast \cdot \text{SE} \quad \text{or} \quad (\hat{p} - z^\ast \cdot \text{SE}, \; \hat{p} + z^\ast \cdot \text{SE}).
\]
To find SE, we substitute \(\hat{p}\) for \(p\), since \(p\) is unknown, and estimate the standard error as \[
  \text{SE}_{\text{est}} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}}.
\]








WarningRemark.



Since the confidence interval calculations are based on the central limit theorem for sample proportions, the conditions for the CLT must be satisfied to create a confidence interval.








NoteConditions for the Central Limit Theorem for Sample Proportions




Sampling is random and independent.
Large sample: The sample size, 𝑛, is large enough to expect at least 10 successes and 10 failures. That is, \(np \geqslant 10\) and \(n(1-p) \geqslant 10\).
Large population: If the sampling is done without replacement, the population must be at least 10 times larger than the sample size.

title: Chapter 7: Survey Sampling and Inference
text:
Section 7.4 Examples






TipExample 1.




QuestionAnswer



During a recent semester, 63 of the 159 MAT 223 students randomly surveyed indicated that they had a negative situation occurred to them based on a posting on social media. Let us estimate the percentage of all Flagler College students who had a negative situation occur to them based on a posting on social media.


What percent of the students surveyed had a negative situation occur to them based on a posting on social media?
What symbol do we use to represent the proportion (percentage) that we calculated in (a)? Is this value a sample statistic or a population parameter?
Check the conditions of the central limit theorem to create a confidence interval.


Is the sample random and independent?
Is the sample size sufficiently large?
Is the population sufficiently large?


Calculate the standard error.
Construct a 95% confidence interval. What is the value of \(z^\ast\)?


Calculate the margin of error.
Find the lower bound of the confidence interval.
Find the upper bound of the confidence interval.


Graph and label the confidence interval.
Interpret the confidence interval.



a. The percentage is \[
\hat{p} = \frac{63}{159} \approx 0.396 \text{ or } 39.6\%.
\] b. The symbol we use to represent the proportion calculated in (a) is \(\hat{p}\). This value is a sample statistic. c. Conditions: - Yes, the sample is random and independent. - Yes, the sample size is sufficiently large since \(n\hat{p} = 159 \times 0.396 \approx 63 \geqslant 10\) and \(n(1-\hat{p}) = 159 \times (1-0.396) \approx 96 \geqslant 10\). - Yes, the population is sufficiently large since the population of Flagler College students is much larger than 10 times the sample size. d. The standard error is estimated as \[
\text{SE}_{\text{est}} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.396(1-0.396)}{159}} \approx 0.0387.
\] e. To construct a 95% confidence interval, we use \(z^\ast = 1.960\). - The margin of error is \[
  m = z^\ast \cdot \text{SE}_{\text{est}} = 1.960 \times 0.0387 \approx 0.0758.
  \] - The lower bound of the confidence interval is \[
  \hat{p} - m = 0.396 - 0.0758 \approx 0.3202.
  \] - The upper bound of the confidence interval is \[
  \hat{p} + m = 0.396 + 0.0758  \approx 0.4718.
  \] g. We are 95% confident that the true proportion of all Flagler College students who had a negative situation occur to them based on a posting on social media is between approximately 32.02% and 47.18%.











TipExample 2.




QuestionAnswer


According to pewresearch.org, a 2014 survey found that 32.1% of adults aged 18–34 were living with their parents. Suppose that this was based on a random sample of 1,200 adults in this age group.

Check that the conditions for the CLT apply.
Use the app to find the confidence interval using confidence levels of 80%, 90%, 95%, and 99% to estimate the population proportion of all Americans in this age group who live with their parents.
What happened to the confidence interval as the level of confidence increases?
Is it plausible to conclude that the true percentage of adults in this age group living with parents is 38%?



a. The sample is random and independent. Since \(n\hat{p} = 1200 \times 0.321 = 385.2 \geqslant 10\) and \(n(1-\hat{p}) = 1200 \times (1-0.321) = 814.8 \geqslant 10\), the sample size is sufficiently large. The population is sufficiently large since the population of adults aged 18–34 is much larger than 10 times the sample size. b. c. As the level of confidence increases, the confidence interval becomes wider. d. We are 99% confident that the true percentage is between 28.6% and 35.6%. Because 38% is not in this interval, it is not plausible that the true percentage is 38%











ImportantImportant



As the confidence level increase, the length of the confidence interval also increases.








TipExample 3.




QuestionAnswer


A political consultant randomly surveys 500 voters in a district to see how many intend to vote for a certain candidate. Of the 500 voters surveyed, 265 indicate they will vote for the candidate. Use a 99% confidence interval, should the consultant predict that the candidate will win the election? Why or why not? (He/she must obtain a simple majority of the votes.)

Verify the conditions for the CLT.
Construct a 99% confidence interval.
Summarize your results.



a. The sample is random and independent. Since \(n\hat{p} = 500 \times 0.53 = 265 \geqslant 10\) and \(n(1-\hat{p}) = 500 \times (1-0.53) = 235 \geqslant 10\), the sample size is sufficiently large. The population is sufficiently large since the population of voters in the district is much larger than 10 times the sample size. b. To construct a 99% confidence interval, we use \(z^\ast = 2.576\). The standard error is estimated as \[
\text{SE}_{\text{est}} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}} = \sqrt{\frac{0.53(1-0.53)}{500}} \approx 0.0223.
\] The margin of error is \[
m = z^\ast \cdot \text{SE}_{\text{est}} = 2.576 \times 0.0223 \approx 0.0574.
\] The lower bound of the confidence interval is \[
\hat{p} - m = 0.53 - 0.0574 \approx 0.4726.
\] The upper bound of the confidence interval is \[
\hat{p} + m = 0.53 + 0.0574  \approx 0.5874.
\] Thus, the 99% confidence interval is \[
(0.4726, \; 0.5874).
\] c. The consultant should only predict a win if the confidence interval only contains values that are greater than 50%. Since the confidence interval includes values less than 0.5, it is not certain that the candidate will win the election.











TipExample 4.




QuestionAnswer


According to housingwire.com, 93.8% of homeowners had “positive equity” in their homes. Suppose that the margin of sampling error is \(\pm 3\) percentage points with a confidence level of 95%.

State the confidence interval in interval notation.
How would you interpret this confidence interval?



a. Note that \(p = 0.938\) and the margin of error is \(m = 0.03\). Thus, the confidence interval is \[
(0.938 - 0.03, 0.938 + 0.03) = (0.908, \; 0.968).
\] b. We are 95% confident that the true proportion of all homeowners who have positive equity in their homes is between 90.8% and 96.8%.
